function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Use of off-the-shelf transducers may lead to inaccuracies in data collection for thermal comfort field studies.","Impact":"Inaccurate data may lead to incorrect conclusions and ineffective strategies for thermal comfort improvement in built environments.","Mitigation":"Calibration and validation of off-the-shelf transducers to ensure accuracy of data collection.","Technologies":"Calibration tools, validation protocols, and quality assurance programs for transducers.","People":"Researchers, scientists, and professionals conducting thermal comfort field studies.","Owner":"Research institutions, regulatory bodies, and standards organizations."},{"Description":"Limited scale and scope of proof-of-concept or project-specific IEQ monitoring systems may hinder their widespread implementation in built environments.","Impact":"Inability to address comprehensive indoor environmental quality (IEQ) issues in large-scale built environments, leading to suboptimal thermal comfort conditions and potential health risks.","Mitigation":"Development of scalable and adaptable IEQ monitoring systems for diverse built environments, incorporating wireless and autonomous technologies for wide sensor coverage.","Technologies":"Wireless sensor networks, autonomous data collection and storage devices, and scalable hardware and software architecture for IEQ monitoring.","People":"Building architects, facility managers, and environmental health professionals responsible for ensuring optimal IEQ in built environments.","Owner":"Technology developers, industry associations, and regulatory bodies."},{"Description":"Shift in technological context to low-cost hardware and open-source software may introduce cybersecurity vulnerabilities in IEQ monitoring systems.","Impact":"Potential data breaches, unauthorized access, and manipulation of sensitive IEQ data, compromising privacy and security in built environments.","Mitigation":"Implementation of robust cybersecurity measures, encryption protocols, and secure data handling practices to protect IEQ monitoring systems from cyber threats.","Technologies":"Cybersecurity software, encryption algorithms, secure communication protocols, and access control mechanisms for IEQ monitoring systems.","People":"Information technology professionals, cybersecurity experts, and data privacy advocates concerned with safeguarding sensitive IEQ data.","Owner":"Technology developers, regulatory bodies, and data security organizations."}]}
